content: How do you say 'where is my dog?' in Paiute?

[{"Where is my dog?": "Hanno 'i-doogü'?"}, {"Where's your dog?": "Hanno 'ü-gwidapugu-uu?"}, {"Where is my rabbit?": "Hanno-wa' i-kammü-naha-uu?"}, {"Where did you spot my dog at (on my behalf)?": "Hanno-kko 'üü 'i-buni-ggü-ti 'i-doogü-tsi'-aa?"}, {"My dog is going alongside the house.": "'I-doogü'-uu 'a-güŵa-duha nobi-neikka mia-ti."}]

["3.1.4.3. Possessive pronouns", "Independent possessive pronouns are mildly emphatic. When used in construction with a possessed nominal, they precede that nominal.", "2.13. Possessives", "Independent possessive pronouns may be used to form an emphatic expression of possession. The independent possessive pronoun directly precedes the possessed noun and must be reiterated by a possessive pronominal prefix.", "In possessive constructions, the possessed nominal must take a possessive pronominal prefix indicating the person and number of the possessor. If present, the possessor nominal may be marked for either accusative or possessive case. Possessive morphology is used to mark the subject of certain nominalizations as well as the object of some postpositions."]
{"haŵutta": "where", "tu'ihanno": "anywhere", "hanno": "where", "hannokko": "where", "'ionnoho": "here"}
{"kwidapugu": "dog", "'ishabugu": "dog", "toogü'": "dog", "pukkupida'": "pet", "toopi": "wolf"}
{"mei": "be", "mai": "be", "mane": "be", "mani": "be", "tüddagai": "born"}
"There was an exact match in my search! "Where is my Dog?" is "Hanno 'i-doogü'?"
What are some words for different animals in Paiute?
{"toopi": "wolf", "pahabichi": "bear", "kwi'naa'": "eagle", "pasagiida'": "hawk", "wükkada": "snake (type)"}
Here are some words for different animals: "pahabichi" means "bear", "kwi'naa'" means "eagle", "pasagiida'" means "hawk", and "wükkada" is snake.
How does sentence structure work in Paiute?

["2.3. Basic Sentence Structure", "3.3. Simple Sentences  
3.3.1. Basic sentence structure  ", "This text is focused on language structure and verb formation in a specific linguistic context.", "The image contains text discussing grammatical structures, particularly focusing on subordinate and main clauses in a language. Here is the rewritten text:", "### Main Text Description:
- The text presents various sentence structures with examples that include:
  - **Questions**: "Are you dancing with Tony?" 
  - **Declarative Sentences**: "My mother's cat is sick."
  - The suffix "-FOC" indicating focus in the sentences.
  
### Example Sentences:
1. "Are you dancing with Tony?"
2. "The cat ran in under Betty's car.""]

I searched the grammar available to me and found that Paiute sentence structure is verb-centered, with flexible word order but a tendency for pronominal subjects to appear after the first word. Verbs carry multiple suffixes marking tense, aspect, and mood, while objects take accusative suffixes, and embedded clauses allow for complex sentence formation.
That rock is going to hit this cat.' in Paiute?

function.name: search_sentences
function.arguments: {"query": "That rock is going to hit this cat."}

content: [{"The one who brought that (rock) could hit us with it.": "'A-wüü-pitü-dü-ii 'a-ŵama-su ta-dabi-kaa."}, {"He hit the window with a rock.": "Na-buni-nnu-nokka tübbi-ma 'u-dabi-ti."}, {"He should do something with that rock because someone else will fall\n                            on it.": "'Uhu-dii-büü hanni'i-mana tübbi-nokka 'u-yügwi-dua-pü pinnahei\n                        haga-sa-mana 'u-ŵan-dugu-su-düa koddoha-wei."}, {"I'm rubbing it into the rock.": "Tübbi-ŵan-dugu nüü 'a-ŵasuuna-ti."}, {"Prop it with the rock.": "'A-zitüdo'mi tübbi-ŵa-ikka."}]
["verb stem - ADV - PL - MODAL - TENSE/ASPECT", "3.2.3.2. Future tense", "2.24.5. Tense and aspect", "3.2.3.1. Present/Past tense x-\"ti ", "3.2.3. Tense and aspect marking"]
{"'ukkahu(na)": "that", "mii": "that", "miihi": "that (quotative)", "'aannihi": "that, like", "'aanni'": "that kind"}
{"tübbi": "rock", "tahani": "pound", "tsügwüda": "hard", "tsitsigigihi": "rattle", "piikwittü": "Mill Creek Rock"}
{"kwia": "hit", "wi'i": "hit (collision)", "tabi": "hit (missile)", "wüttabi": "hit (missile)", "topagitta": "hit with fist"}
{"kiidi'": "cat", "'ishabugu": "dog", "kwidapugu": "dog", "ka'udza'": "fox sp.", "wiheetsiti": "mountain lion"}
{"-geidü": "go", "-gaidü": "go", "-kimma": "come", "pügügühi": "go (strugglingly)", "-kai": "go"}

Response: I searched available translations and identified tübbi for “rock,” kiidi’ for “cat,” and gwati-gaa-wei as a future-tense form of “hit.” I followed common Paiute verb structure by placing the verb at the end and marking future intent through suffixes. Resulting in a final tranlation of tübbi-uu kidi'-eika ma-gwati-gaa-wei. Please know that this is the best guess tranlation and may have errors.
That dog is chasing that bear.' in Paiute?

[{"The bear eats all the fish.": "Pahabichi-ii-bünno' pagwi-neikka nasümü-ggu tüka-tei-ti."}, {"The bear is standing up (on its hind legs).": "Nawaawünü-ti pahabichi-uu."}, {"The bear does that. It goes towards it's burrow and then proceeds to\n                            hibernate there.": "'Uhu pahabichi-uu 'unnihi mani-dü. 'Uhu tü-do'oo-gwee-tugu mia-ti\n                        'oonno'oho 'oottogo-ho 'üwi-ku-ka'."}, {"The coyote was acting ambitiously.": "'Isha'-uu-bünno' naamüdüyaa-dü."}, {"The bears are all *sleeping at this time.": "Mii'ukka pahabichi-uu-büü 'ükooi-nawi-ti."}]

["3.1.4.3. Possessive pronouns", "Independent possessive pronouns are mildly emphatic. When used in construction with a possessed nominal, they precede that nominal.", "2.13. Possessives", "Independent possessive pronouns may be used to form an emphatic expression of possession. The independent possessive pronoun directly precedes the possessed noun and must be reiterated by a possessive pronominal prefix.", "In possessive constructions, the possessed nominal must take a possessive pronominal prefix indicating the person and number of the possessor. If present, the possessor nominal may be marked for either accusative or possessive case. Possessive morphology is used to mark the subject of certain nominalizations as well as the object of some postpositions."]
{"'ukkahu(na)": "that", "mii": "that", "miihi": "that (quotative)", "'aannihi": "that, like", "'aanni'": "that kind"}
{"kwidapugu": "dog", "toogü'": "dog", "'ishabugu": "dog", "pukkupida'": "pet", "'uunuppi": "wolf"}
{"maŵia": "chase", "manüŵi": "chase", "magimma": "chase", "tümahi": "pursue", "tübbaŵahi": "chaw"}
{"pahabichi": "bear", "puudu'": "bull", "'uunuppi": "wolf", "'ahibuggu": "bull", "toopi": "wolf"}
{"-honno": "with", "pahükkabü": "ice", "'uhuŵa": "they", "-düasu": "also", "yahiimü": "inlaws"}

I searched available translations and identified isha'pugu for “dog,” pahabichi for “bear,” and naki-ti as the present tense form of “chase.” I applied the distal marker -uu to the subject and -noka to the object to express “that dog” and “that bear,” respectively. For the verb, I selected u- to indicate a third-person object and added -ti for present tense. Resulting in a final tranlation of 'isha'pugu-uu pahabichi-noka u-naki-ti'. Please know that this is the best guess tranlation and may have errors.
They are visiting the jackrabbit.' in Paiute?

[{"The jackrabbit burrows and lives among the brush.": "Kammü-uu-bünno' asi-'aka tohooi-shi katü-ti."}, {"What (now), in order for us to snare the jackrabbits.": "Hiibü-nokka, kammü-nokka 'u-hüa-wei-shu-daagwa-düa."}, {"Trap some jackrabbits.": "Kammü-na 'u-hüa."}, {"He just scurries about chasing jackrabbits.": "'Uhu tünaa pizhibüdüddühi-tei-ti kammü-na maŵia-si."}, {"We go get jackrabbit from the open country, then skin that, and eat.": "Nüügwa tsaŵu tüboona-ddü-aa 'ia kammü-ga-tuha-si 'ukkahuna 'u-zakwadda-si\n                        tüka-dü."}]

["3.1.4.3. Possessive pronouns", "Independent possessive pronouns are mildly emphatic. When used in construction with a possessed nominal, they precede that nominal.", "2.13. Possessives", "Independent possessive pronouns may be used to form an emphatic expression of possession. The independent possessive pronoun directly precedes the possessed noun and must be reiterated by a possessive pronominal prefix.", "In possessive constructions, the possessed nominal must take a possessive pronominal prefix indicating the person and number of the possessor. If present, the possessor nominal may be marked for either accusative or possessive case. Possessive morphology is used to mark the subject of certain nominalizations as well as the object of some postpositions."]
{"'uhuŵa": "they", "ui-": "them", "mahuŵa": "those", "'ai-": "them", "nüügwa": "we"}
{"nobini": "visit", "pasiaana'i": "visit", "kimmakudü": "welcome", "puni": "see", "pitaŵa": "look"}
{"kammü": "jackrabbit", "kammüna uboggina": "rabbit boss", "wiga": "rabbit blanket", "kammüyahi": "rabbit drive", "tabuu'tsi'": "cottontail rabbit"}
{"nobini": "visit", "pasiaana'i": "visit", "-wee": "at, to", "kimmakudü": "welcome", "-wii": "at, to"}

I searched available translations and identified kammü for “jackrabbit,” nobini for “visit,” and 'uhuw̃a for “they.” I used -noka on kammü to mark “the jackrabbit” as a distal object and added u- as the object marker on the verb. I then combined nobini with the present tense suffix -ti to form “are visiting.” The final translation was: 'kamü-noka uhuw̃a u-nobini-ti'. Please know that this is the best guess tranlation and may have errors.
